tutorial_source: YouTube: Chevifier - Quest Manager For Godot 4
instruction: Wire a CanvasLayer quest HUD that registers the Shoot Em Up quest resource, connects the QuestManager step_updated, step_complete, quest_completed, and quest_failed signals, formats incremental and timer step text, and fails the quest whenever the player HP reaches zero.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Chevifier - Quest Manager For Godot 4
instruction: Make the projectile advance the Shoot Em Up quest by calling QuestManager.progress_quest with the kill step each time it overlaps an enemy, queue_free itself after the hit, and ensure it also removes itself when it travels far off screen (50 pixels).

tutorial_source: YouTube: CyberPotato - [BETTER SOUND REUPLOAD] How to make River Raid Atari Classic in Godot 4 - Tutorial
instruction: Create a Player scene with a CharacterBody2D root named Player, add an AnimatedSprite2D that autoplay the default animation and includes looping default/left/right jet frames from assets/sprites/sprites-Sheet.png and a non-looping explode sequence from the smoke sprites at assets/sprites/Free Smoke Fx  Pixel 04.png, and attach a 16×16 rectangular CollisionShape2D that fits the jet.

tutorial_source: YouTube: CyberPotato - [BETTER SOUND REUPLOAD] How to make River Raid Atari Classic in Godot 4 - Tutorial
instruction: Create a Missile scene with an Area2D root named Missile, set its collision layer to 4 and mask to 26, add a Sprite2D that enables region mode to crop the 4×4 missile sprite from sprites-Sheet.png at region Rect2(69, 0, 4, 4), attach a 4×4 rectangular CollisionShape2D, and include a VisibleOnScreenNotifier2D scaled to Vector2(0.2, 0.2).

tutorial_source: YouTube: CyberPotato - [BETTER SOUND REUPLOAD] How to make River Raid Atari Classic in Godot 4 - Tutorial
instruction: Create a UI scene with a CanvasLayer root named UI. Add a ControlPanelRect ColorRect (with the bottom-wide anchor mode and a custom minimum height of 58) tinted grey (rgba = (0.6, 0.6, 0.6, 1.0)), place Lives: 3 and Points: 0 labels inside it (with names LivesLabel and PointsLabel), and add PowerMeter and PowerIndicator TextureRects inside it that use Fuel-Meter.png and Fuel-Indicator.png respectively with the meter being bottom-anchored and centered. Include a hidden GameOverView CenterContainer containing a ColorRect (with name ColorRect), and add a GAME OVER label inside the ColorRect (with name Label).

tutorial_source: YouTube: GodotGameLab - Godot 4 Autobattler Tutorial: RefCounted, FSM & UnitAI (S02E06)
instruction: In res://scenes/battle_unit/battle_unit.tscn add a Label child named FSMDebugLabel above the sprite (offsets -65,-47 to 65,-29) with centered text reading IDLE, then add a UnitAI node that uses res://scenes/battle_unit/ai/unit_ai.gd and wire its exported debug_label to FSMDebugLabel and actor to the BattleUnit root so the finite state machine component can update the on-screen state indicator.

tutorial_source: YouTube: GodotGameLab - Slay the Spire Clone Godot 4 Tutorial: Stats with Resources (04/08)
instruction: Implement res://scripts/card_pile.gd for the Card Pile resource. Register class_name CardPile, export an Array[Card], and declare the card_pile_size_changed(cards_amount) signal. Provide helpers empty(), draw_card(), add_card(), shuffle(), clear(), and _to_string(). draw_card() must pop the front card, emit the new count, and return the card (or null if empty). add_card() appends a card and emits the new size, shuffle() randomizes the Array in place, clear() empties the pile and emits zero, and _to_string() should list each card as 'index: card_id' on its own line (this should be human readable, so start with 1 index). Use the supplied Card resource for typing.

tutorial_source: YouTube: GodotGameLab - Slay the Spire Clone Godot 4 Tutorial: Stats with Resources (04/08)
instruction: Turn res://scenes/stats_ui.tscn into the StatsUI overlay from the tutorial. Use an HBoxContainer root anchored to the center (about 90×16) with theme res://assets/main_theme.tres and alignment set to Center. Add two child HBoxContainers named Block and Health; set Block's separation override to 0 and Health's to 2. Inside each container create a TextureRect and a Label: BlockImage must use res://assets/sprites/tile_0102.png, HealthImage must use res://assets/sprites/heart.png, and both TextureRects should keep aspect (stretch_mode = 5). Give the labels unique_name_in_owner=true, center their horizontal and vertical alignment, and seed placeholder numbers. Attach res://scripts/stats_ui.gd, register class_name StatsUI, and implement update_stats(stats: Stats) so it writes the block/health values to the labels and hides each container when its value is zero.

tutorial_source: YouTube: HullHound - Level up Your Game Development Skills: Learn to Make Frogger in Godot 4 - Part 5
instruction: Clone the SafePlatform scene into an UnsafePlatform that warns players before it drops them. Add an AnimationPlayer with an UnsafeCycle animation that autoplays, keyframe Area2D.modulate through calm white, brighter orange, and a red danger state, and in the same animation toggle Area2D.process_mode to PROCESS_MODE_DISABLED during the red window so the safety area truly disappears.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Game Dev Artisan - Adding Collisions: Layers, Detections, and Interactions - Godot Fundamentals
instruction: Build res://scenes/entities/world/pickup.tscn with an Area2D root named Pickup that uses res://scripts/entities/world/pickup.gd, add a Sprite2D using assets/sprites/pickups.png, a CollisionShape2D using an 8×8 RectangleShape2D, and an AudioStreamPlayer on the SFX bus that plays assets/audio/sfx/pickup.wav. Connect the root's body_entered signal to _on_body_entered, and in that method ensure Tank bodies call Tank.collect(self) before the pickup plays the audio, waits for it to finish, and queue_frees itself. Instance the pickup in res://scenes/main.tscn with the name 'Pickup' at position (64, 0) with scale (4, 4).

tutorial_source: YouTube: Game Dev Artisan - Adding Collisions: Layers, Detections, and Interactions - Godot Fundamentals
instruction: Create res://scenes/entities/tank/weapon/bullet.tscn with an Area2D root named Bullet that uses res://scripts/entities/tank/weapon/bullet.gd, set its collision_layer to 16 and collision_mask to 44, add a 3×3 rectangular CollisionShape2D plus a Sprite2D with a texture, and connect both area_entered and body_entered signals to the Bullet script handlers.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Game Dev Artisan - Adding Collisions: Layers, Detections, and Interactions - Godot Fundamentals
instruction: Update res://scripts/entities/tank/weapon/bullet.gd so the Bullet has const SPEED = 500, stores its travel direction and firing tank, moves every physics frame by direction.normalized() * SPEED * delta, queues itself when area_entered fires, and on body_entered destroys Crate bodies before calling queue_free().

tutorial_source: YouTube: GodotGameLab - Godot 4 Autobattler Tutorial: RefCounted, FSM & UnitAI (S02E06)
instruction: Implement res://components/state.gd so State._init(new_actor) stores the provided actor reference, and complete res://components/finite_state_machine.gd by declaring a state_changed(new_state) signal plus a change_state(new_state) method that calls exit() on the previous state, enter() on the new state, updates the state property, and emits state_changed after every transition.

task_name: Build the gritty world environment stack
tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Basic Post Processing in Godot 4
instruction: Under Main, configure the WorldEnvironment so its Environment keeps the procedural sky background (background_mode = Sky) with the ProceduralSkyMaterial's sky colors set to Color(0.5216, 0.6706, 0.7922), switches to ACES tone mapping, enables SSR with 128 max steps and 0.51 depth tolerance, enables SSAO at intensity 5.54, enables SDFGI with occlusion (bounce feedback 1.44, 6 cascades, 0.1 min cell size), and activates glow using LensDirtTexture.png with normalized screen blend (intensity 4.33, strength 0.88, bloom 0.05).

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Basic Post Processing in Godot 4
instruction: Enable depth fog in the shared WorldEnvironment, tint it to Color(0.5176, 0.5529, 0.6196) with density 0.001 and sky affect 0.147, enable volumetric fog with albedo Color(0.8706, 0.7961, 0.7726), and turn on Adjustments so the color correction slot uses the provided ExtremeLUT.png Texture3D as its lookup table.

task_name: Install the cultist flashlight priority marker
tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Dynamic Targeting Plus Custom Array Sorting - Making a FPS Horror Game (GDScript) | 12
instruction: In scenes/cultist_prefab.tscn add a FlashlightPoint instance (point_of_interest.tscn) under ChestMarkerContainer so Main/Cultist exposes a child named FlashlightPoint that belongs to the FlashlightPoints group and has its priority set to High. Leave the existing ChestTarget marker alone; only wire up the high-priority flashlight anchor.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Implementing Basic Procedual Animation - Making a FPS Horror Game (GDScript) | 07
instruction: Inside Main/Cultist/CultistBody/CultistRig/Skeleton3D, create four SkeletonIK3D nodes named Hand_R_IK, Hand_L_IK, Foot_R_IK, and Foot_L_IK. Configure their root/tip bones exactly as in the video (upper_arm.R → hand.R, upper_arm.L → hand.L, thigh.R → foot.R, thigh.L → foot.L), enable magnet support, and point each solver’s target_node at the matching IK target container (RightHandTargetContainer/Hand_R_Target, LeftHandTargetContainer/Hand_L_Target, etc.).

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Making a FPS Horror Game (C#) | 03 | Gun Mechanics
instruction: In scenes/main.tscn, finish the arms rig so BarrelEnd has a RayCast3D child that points straight 1000 units forward (facing away from camera), then add a WeaponEffectsController node under ArmsRig that uses scripts/weapon_effects_controller.gd. Assign its Barrel End and Barrel RayCast exports to the nodes you just created and point the PackedScene exports at scenes/effects/muzzle_flash_effect.tscn and scenes/effects/impact_effect.tscn. Finally, hook PlayerBody's gun_effects export up to the new controller so the CharacterBody3D script can call FireRevolver and Reload.

task_name: Build the muzzle flash effect prefab
tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Making a FPS Horror Game (C#) | 03 | Gun Mechanics
instruction: Create a layered muzzle flash prefab: edit scenes/effects/muzzle_flash_effect.tscn so the root Node3D uses scripts/generic_effect_handler.gd, targets its Optional Light export at an OmniLight child named MuzzleFlash, and keeps a 0.2 second fade. Add SmokeParticles configured with zero gravity and a StandardMaterial3D mesh using a radial GradientTexture2D. Simulate a volumetric smoke puff using the particle billboard mode for billboarding, plus a pair of opposing GPUParticles3D named MuzzleFireLeft and MuzzleFireRight that emit one-shot bursts. Each muzzle fire particle system must rely on the provided assets/shaders/muzzle_flash.gdshader ShaderMaterial and include a draw-pass QuadMesh so the burst renders from both sides. Wire the scene into scenes/main.tscn so Main instantiates the finished effect.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Menus and Transitions! - FPS Horror Project (GDScript) | 19
instruction: Create res://scenes/menus.tscn as a Control named Menus that fills the viewport, keeps process mode Always, and uses scripts/menu_handler.gd. Add three hidden panels, all centered with anchors at 0.5: LaunchMenu (offsets: -205, -196 to 205, 196), PauseMenu (offsets: -205, -196 to 205, 45), and RestartMenu (offsets: -205, -196 to 205, 63). Give LaunchMenu a VBoxContainer with two labels, `Label` writing 'FPS Horror' and `Label2` writing 'By Bonkahe'; give PauseMenu a VBoxContainer containing label `Label` writing 'Paused'; and give RestartMenu a VBoxContainer containing label node `Label` writing 'You Died'. Add the appropriate buttons (FullScreenButton, PlayButton, QuitButton, ResumeButton, RestartButton) to the vbox containers of each panel using 31pt font overrides and exact node names. Finally, add a CanvasLayer on layer 2 with a TransitionOverlay ColorRect that ignores mouse input and stretches to the viewport; assign assets/materials/menu_overlay_material.tres to it, export the LaunchMenu/PauseMenu/DeathMenu references on the root, and connect every button’s pressed signal to the proper menu handler method (ToggleFullScreen, BeginLaunch, HidePauseMenu, RestartLevel, ExitGame).

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Menus and Transitions! - FPS Horror Project (GDScript) | 19
instruction: In res://scenes/level.tscn add a Camera3D named LevelCamera that matches the static menu shot (use position roughly -12.22, 15.83, 12.44 and use the rotation basis vectors (0.794097, 0.0, 0.607792), (0.37447, 0.787656, -0.489255), (-0.478731, 0.616115, 0.625475); leave current disabled). Instance res://scenes/player_body.tscn and res://scenes/menus.tscn under the Level root so the player and menu prefab exist together, then assign the menu handler exports so PlayerNode points to the PlayerBody node, LevelCamera points to the new LevelCamera, and the TransitionMaterial remains the provided shader material. The Menus instance must stay linked to scenes/menus.tscn and sit alongside the player so the handler can hide the player, drive the LevelCamera, and run transitions while the tree is paused.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Cashew OldDew - Signals in Godot 4.3
instruction: Add a Node2D named SpawningPoints under the Trap node. Inside SpawningPoints, create two Marker2D children named SpawnTop and SpawnBot. Place SpawnTop at position (0, 15) and SpawnBot at position (0, -15). Set SpawnBot's z_index to 1.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Cashew OldDew - Signals in Godot 4.3
instruction: In res://scenes/main.tscn, use the existing Main (Node2D) root and existing Player (CharacterBody2D) node. Add a CanvasLayer named HUD with a Label called DamageLabel that starts at "Total Damage: 0", and connect Player.taken_damage to Main._on_player_taken_damage so the label updates each time Player.take_damage emits 20 damage.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Basic Inventory System [Part 1] - Godot 4.x
instruction: Author res://scripts/interactable_item.gd so it extends Node3D with class_name InteractableItem, exports a MeshInstance3D named item_highlight_mesh, hides that mesh in _ready(), and provides gain_focus() / lose_focus() methods that toggle its visibility. Attach the script to the RigidBody3D in res://scenes/item_pickup.tscn, set its collision_layer to 2, collision_mask to 3, assign MeshInstance3D/Highlight to the export, and ensure the Highlight child stays hidden by default while using an emissive StandardMaterial3D for its outline. Create res://scripts/item_data.gd as a Resource with exported item_name (String) and item_model_prefab (PackedScene), then add res://resources/items/test_cube.tres using that script so it stores the name "Test Cube" and points item_model_prefab to res://scenes/item_pickup.tscn. Leave the ItemPickup instance in res://scenes/main.tscn so the prefab is visible in the scene tree.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Basic Inventory System [Part 1] - Godot 4.x
instruction: Implement res://scripts/player_interaction_handler.gd so it extends Area3D with class_name PlayerInteractionHandler, defines an item_picked_up(item_data: ItemData) signal, exports item_types: Array[ItemData], tracks nearby_bodies: Array[InteractableItem], listens for the 'interact' input action in _input(), and runs pickup_nearest_item() to remove the closest InteractableItem, queue_free it, and match its PackedScene path against the exported ItemData array before emitting the signal. Provide _on_body_entered() / _on_body_exited() methods that gain and lose focus on interactables and keep nearby_bodies in sync. Attach this script to PlayerBody/InteractionArea inside res://scenes/main.tscn, set its collision_layer to 0, collision_mask to 2, connect body_entered and body_exited to the script methods, and assign res://resources/items/test_cube.tres plus res://resources/items/test_sphere.tres to the exported array so pickups can be identified. Update project.godot to define an 'interact' action bound to the F key so the handler receives the input.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Adding a bit of JUICE (Camera Shake & Head Bob) - FPS Horror Project (C#) | 13
instruction: In scenes/player_body.tscn, restructure PlayerBody so CameraNode contains a CameraActual Node3D with a Camera3D child, assign those nodes to the player_body.gd exports, and implement a noise-based camera shake: expose a FastNoiseLite plus numeric exports for noise_panning_speed (30), max_power (0.15), blend_speed (7), return_strength (5), noise_strength (0.2), falling_bias (1.0), falling_strength_falloff (2.0), falling_max_strength (1.0), and jumping_strength (0.2). Track camera_shake_position/time_since_started, lerp CameraActual toward camera_shake_position plus sampled noise every physics frame, decay back to origin, clamp impulses to the max power, add an upward kick inside impulse_camera_with_recoil, and implement apply_landing_impulse() so downward velocities below the bias trigger a proportional drop impulse. In the PlayerBody scene, create a FastNoiseLite resource with default values and wire it to the camera shake export.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Adding a bit of JUICE (Camera Shake & Head Bob) - FPS Horror Project (C#) | 13
instruction: In scenes/weapon_rig.tscn, expose WeaponEffects with BarrelEnd/BarrelRayCast exports plus a camera_shake_power export set to 0.3, declare the on_shot_camera_impulse(Vector3,float) signal in scripts/weapon_effects.gd, and emit it from fire_weapon() using the normalized -BarrelRayCast global forward direction and the exported power. Update player_body.gd to include apply_weapon_impulse() that forwards to impulse_camera_with_recoil(), and connect the weapon signal to that method inside scenes/main.tscn so firing the weapon instantly kicks the PlayerBody camera backward.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Flashlight Collision Plus Dynamic Targeting - Making a FPS Horror Game (C#) | 12
instruction: Create a reusable FlashlightPoint marker scene that uses scripts/flashlight_point.gd to expose a Priority enum (low, medium, high), a has_been_targeted flag, and a reset_target_state() helper, then instance three FlashlightPoint nodes directly under Main in scenes/main.tscn. Place the nodes at (8.36166, 1.81915, -12.0301), (-16.6577, 2.41884, -39.9426), and (23.0185, 2.63927, -86.6948), keep them in the FlashlightPoints group, and set their priorities to medium, low, and high respectively.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Implementing AI spawning triggers and Aggro! - FPS Horror Project (GDScript) | 14
instruction: Attach res://scripts/TriggerVolume.gd to NavigationRegion3D/Triggers/SpawnTrigger1 so its TriggerVolume_BodyEntered handler queue_frees the trigger after the wave fires. Implement res://scripts/EnemySpawnPoint.gd with exports for variables named EnemyPackedScene, AutoSetTarget, and TargetToSet, then attach it to EnemySpawnPointA, EnemySpawnPointB, and EnemySpawnPointC. Each spawn point must instantiate the Cultist scene, add it beside the marker, copy the marker transform, call PlaceOnMesh() on the EnemyAIController, and when AutoSetTarget is true call SetNodeTarget() with PlayerBody. Wire SpawnTrigger1's body_entered signal to every spawn point's SpawnInitiated method and assign EnemyPackedScene to res://scenes/Cultist.tscn with TargetToSet pointing to PlayerBody so the trigger spawns three enemies aimed at the player.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Implementing Volumetric Clouds Easy
instruction: Under Main, add a SunshineCloudsDriver node that uses addons/SunshineClouds2/SunshineCloudsDriver.gd, enable Update Continuously, and assign res://assets/clouds/tutorial_clouds_settings.tres to its clouds_resource while reusing the WorldEnvironment environment as ambience_sample_environment. Register the existing DirectionalLight3D and OmniLight3D inside tracked_directional_lights and tracked_point_lights (with a single shadow step entry set to 32) so the clouds use those lights, keep the OmniLight range at 20000, and extend Camera3D's far clip plane to 400000. Wire the same clouds resource into the WorldEnvironment's compositor effect list so the effect renders, and edit assets/clouds/tutorial_clouds_settings.tres to match the reference settings: cloud coverage 0.874, atmospheric density 0.617977, cloud ambient color pure white, ambient tint Color(0.131626, 0.201524, 0.241773, 1), atmosphere color Color(0.696127, 0.832325, 0.989334, 1), and a 512 km mask width so the painted area covers the entire level.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Godot 3D - Implementing Volumetric Clouds Easy
instruction: Reuse the supplied volumetric clouds setup but finish the advanced controls: configure OmniLight3D as the warm point light: (color Color(0.76, 0.374933, 0.1824, 1), energy 11.685, range 20000, positioned at (10743.6, 6693.89, -43458.2)) and add it to SunshineCloudsDriver.tracked_point_lights. Instance a SunshineCloudsEffector under Main using addons/SunshineClouds2/SunshineCloudEffector.gd, place it at (19316.8, -2863.07, -3971.34) with Radius 18900.9 and Power 1.18, and assign it through tracked_point_effectors so moving the effector sculpts the clouds. Configure the wind controls by setting the driver's wind_direction to Vector3(1, 0, 1) with speeds 140 (extra large), 100 (large), 40 (medium), and 12 (small). Finally, open assets/clouds/mask_clouds_settings.tres and re-enable the painted mask by turning extra_large_used_as_mask back on, keeping mask_width_km at 512 km, and restoring a dense coverage value (0.874) so the flood-filled mask blankets the play space.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Pretty Much Everything About GPUParticles in Godot 4
instruction: Complete the unfinished SmokeEmitter under Main: set the GPUParticles3D amount to 32, lifetime to 8 seconds, and draw order to View Depth, then attach a ParticleProcessMaterial that emits from a 1m sphere, keeps direction (0, 1, 0), adds gravity (0, 3, 0), uses 0.5 lifetime randomness, full ±180° angles with ±10 deg/sec angular velocity, 0.3 damping, scale 25–30 controlled by a CurveTexture, a GradientTexture1D that fades from transparent to opaque back to transparent, animation speed 0.5–1.0 with 0.1 offset, and turbulence enabled with ~0.02 influence. Provide a QuadMesh draw pass, assign the StandardMaterial3D override to res://assets/sprites/particle_sprite_smoke.webp, turn on particle billboarding with keep scale, configure an 8×8 flipbook that does not loop, and enable the proximity/distance fades so the smoke sprite blends out.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Pretty Much Everything About GPUParticles in Godot 4
instruction: Finish the Explosion hierarchy so the ArcingChunks emitter works as wanted: set ArcingChunks to one_shot, lifetime 3s, randomness about 0.7, give it a QuadMesh draw pass and a StandardMaterial3D billboard with bright emission, and drive it with a ParticleProcessMaterial that fires from the default spread at 8–12 m/s, enables rigid collision with bounce 1.0, uses collision_use_scale, and sets a constant sub emitter frequency of 100 Hz with the sub_emitter path pointing to ../ArcingChunkSmoke. Add the GPUParticlesCollisionBox3D named ArcingChunkCollision, positioned just below the emitter and scaled to 40×1×40 so debris collides as shown in the collision segment of the video. Configure ArcingChunkSmoke to emit ~1000 particles with a ShaderMaterial referencing res://assets/shaders/SmokeShader.gdshader (NoiseTexture = res://assets/shaders/NoiseResource.tres) and a ParticleProcessMaterial that rotates sprites, uses the warm gradient/curve combo from the repo, lifetime 3 s, gravity (0,1,0), linear accel ~2, scale curve peaks between 8 and 15, and turbulence influence about 0.005–0.01 so the smoke puffs appear along the chunk trails.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Cashew OldDew - Debug Visually in Godot 4.2
instruction: Inside the SteerComponent script, capture the current velocity, scaled desired velocity, and steering force in a debug dictionary whenever debugging is enabled, and queue a redraw every frame so the overlay can update.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Cashew OldDew - Debug Visually in Godot 4.2
instruction: Use the SteerComponent's _draw function to render the velocity vector in black, the desired velocity in red, a blue connector between them, and circles at both tips so the steering forces are visible during play.

tutorial_source: YouTube: GodotGameLab - Godot 4 Autobattler Tutorial: Introduction (S1 INTRO)
instruction: Make the trait panel behave like the tutorial's left-column tracker. In res://scenes/trait_ui/trait_ui.tscn keep the existing node hierarchy but complete trait_ui.gd so that exporting trait_data: Trait populates the icon and name label, update(units) counts the number of unique unit names that include that trait, writes the count to %ActiveUnitsLabel, formats the threshold RichTextLabel with the BBCode returned by the Trait resource, and toggles the panel alpha to 1.0 when active and 0.5 when inactive. The Trait resource provided in data/traits must drive all text, and Main.tscn should keep instancing the TraitUI scene with the elf trait assigned.

tutorial_source: YouTube: GodotGameLab - Godot 4 Autobattler Tutorial: Introduction (S1 INTRO)
instruction: Finish res://scenes/sell_portal/sell_portal.gd so the Area2D behaves like a selling portal. Keep the OutlineHighlighter and FlipSprite nodes wired to the CanvasGroup + Sprite2D, scan the "units" group in _ready() and call setup_unit(unit) to connect each unit's DragAndDrop.dropped and quick_sell_pressed signals. When a unit overlaps the portal, highlight the outline, face the sprite toward the unit each frame, show the %Gold container, and set %GoldLabel to unit.stats.get_gold_value(). When the unit exits, clear current_unit, hide the gold preview, and reset the outline. Dropping or quick-selling while hovered must call _sell_unit, which adds the unit's gold value to player_stats.gold, pushes the stats back into the exported unit_pool, and removes and queue_free()s the unit. The provided Main.tscn should continue instancing SellPortal.tscn with its exported resources assigned.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Godotneers - Particle Systems in Godot - Part 1: Getting started in 2D
instruction: Finish res://scenes/main.tscn so Rain's GPUParticles2D fills the 1800px-wide sky, emits ~800 drops for 5s with a 10s preprocess, 600-850 initial velocity along (0.1, 1, 0), scale 0.2-1.0, hide-on-contact collisions (base size ≈5), and a visibility rect that covers the whole screen (suppose the screen is 1800x900, starting at around (-900, -200)). Wire its sub_emitter to Splash and set the ParticleProcessMaterial to a box emission 900px wide with four Splash particles per collision. Configure Splash with its own ParticleProcessMaterial (align_y=true, 6400 amount, explosiveness 1, 50-60 velocity, gravity 98, scale 0.1-0.2) so Rain collisions burst extra droplets. Keep GroundOccluder and GroundCollider covering the floor so collisions work.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Godotneers - Particle Systems in Godot - Part 1: Getting started in 2D
instruction: Add a GPUParticles2D named SmokeStylized under Campfire in res://scenes/main.tscn that uses the smokelet texture and emits ~12 particles with lifetime 15s and preprocess 20s. Configure its ParticleProcessMaterial with zero gravtiy, initial velocity direction (0.2, -1, 0), 30-50 initial velocity, -30 to 30 directional velocity whose sway is driven by a CurveXYZTexture with 3 or more points on the X curve. Configure ParticleProcessMaterial's display to grow the streaks to 3x size using scale max = 3 and a scale CurveTexture; also use a color ramp GradientTexture1D (orange near flame → gray mid-air → transparent). Enable trails (5s lifetime, ≥32 sections, ≥32 subdivisions) so the smoke forms continuous ribbons above the flame.

tutorial_source: YouTube: HullHound - How to add a Day Night Cycle to your game | Godot 4
instruction: Finish res://scenes/Main.tscn by wiring the provided day-night scripts to the existing SunLight, ClockLabel, and PorchLight. Under Main add a Node named DayNightCycle that runs scripts/day_night/DayNightCycleNode.gd and give it four children: LightColorTransition, SampledObjectRotator, TimeHandler, and LightIntensityTransition. LightColorTransition must use scripts/day_night/LightColorTransitionNode.gd, target ../../SunLight, and its gradient must have stops at offsets 0.00 and 1.00 with Color(0.05, 0.05, 0.08), 0.25 and 0.75 with Color(0.97, 0.64, 0.28), and 0.50 with Color(0.98, 0.98, 0.94). SampledObjectRotator must use scripts/day_night/SampledObjectRotatorNode.gd, target ../../SunLight, and its X rotation curve needs two points so the samples return ≈0° at 0.0, ≈180° at 0.5, and ≈360° at 1.0; leave Y/Z curves flat. TimeHandler must run scripts/day_night/TimeHandler.gd with day_length_seconds = 10 and display_interval_minutes = 10. LightIntensityTransition must use scripts/day_night/LightIntensityTransitionNode.gd, target ../../SunLight, and its curve must keep intensity ≤0.2 at 0.0 and 1.0 but ≈1.1 at 0.5 (three control points at 0.0→0.1, 0.5→1.1, 1.0→0.1 works). tutorial_source: YouTube: DevPoodle - Making a 3D Outline Effect - Using Godot Engine
instruction: Implement `res://scripts/outline_effect.gd` and `res://outline.glsl` for a depth-based outline compositor effect. The script must include `@tool`, `extends CompositorEffect`, and `class_name OutlineEffect`. It must use `RenderingServer.get_rendering_device()` and create the compute pipeline with `rd.compute_pipeline_create`, a parameter storage buffer with `storage_buffer_create`, and a depth sampler with `sampler_create`. In the render callback, it must call `get_render_scene_buffers`, `get_internal_size`, `get_color_layer(0)`, and `get_depth_layer(0)`, update the buffer with `buffer_update`, create the uniform set with `uniform_set_create`, and dispatch with `compute_list_dispatch`. The shader must be a compute shader (`#[compute]`) with `layout(local_size_x = 8` and declare the params buffer as `readonly buffer Params` that includes `mat4 inv_proj_mat`. It must bind the color image as `uniform image2D color_image` and the depth texture as `sampler2D depth_texture` (with `binding = 0` on the params buffer). The shader must use `gl_GlobalInvocationID`, call a `get_linear_depth` function, use a `sample_size` radius to compare neighboring depths, and write the outlined color back with `imageStore`.

In `scripts/tank.gd`, track the current particle gradient using `World.get_gradient_at(position)`, assign it to each emitter’s `process_material.color_ramp`, set both emitters to `emitting = true` while moving, and `emitting = false` when not moving.

task_name: Basic Triplanar Shader on a Sphere
tutorial_source: YouTube: DevPoodle - Texturing Without UV's (An Intro to Triplanar Mapping) - Using Godot Engine
instruction: Create a Node3D scene with a MeshInstance3D sphere that uses a SphereMesh and a ShaderMaterial assigned to the SphereMesh material. Write a spatial shader at res://scripts/triplanar_basic.gdshader that projects a single texture along the X, Y, and Z axes using world-space vertex coordinates and normal-weighted blending. In fragment(), define `vec4 vertex = INV_VIEW_MATRIX * vec4(VERTEX, 1.0)` and `vec3 normal = normalize((INV_VIEW_MATRIX * vec4(NORMAL, 0.0)).xyz)`. Define `vec3 adjusted_normal = abs(normal)` and `vec3 weights = adjusted_normal / (adjusted_normal.x + adjusted_normal.y + adjusted_normal.z)`. Define `vec2 uv_x = vertex.zy`, `vec2 uv_y = vertex.xz`, and `vec2 uv_z = vertex.xy`. Sample a single `uniform sampler2D texture_x` with `uv_x`, `uv_y`, and `uv_z`, multiply each sample by the corresponding weight, and set `ALBEDO = color_x + color_y + color_z`. Assign any texture to the shader parameter `texture_x`.

task_name: Axis Textures and Top-Only Grass Triplanar Shader
tutorial_source: YouTube: DevPoodle - Texturing Without UV's (An Intro to Triplanar Mapping) - Using Godot Engine
instruction: Create a Node3D root named Main with a MeshInstance3D child named Sphere. Assign a SphereMesh to Sphere.mesh and assign a ShaderMaterial to that SphereMesh. The ShaderMaterial must use a shader at res://scripts/triplanar_axis_blend.gdshader. In that shader, declare uniforms `uniform sampler2D texture_x`, `uniform sampler2D texture_y`, and `uniform sampler2D texture_z`. Implement triplanar blending with normal-based weights and exact lines: `vec3 adjusted_normal = pow(abs(normal), vec3(8.0))`, `float use_y_up = float(normal.y > 0.0)`, `vec3 color_y_up = texture(texture_y, uv_y).rgb * weights.y`, `vec3 color_y_down = texture(texture_x, uv_y).rgb * weights.y`, `mix(color_y_down, color_y_up, use_y_up)`, and `ALBEDO = (color_x + mix(color_y_down, color_y_up, use_y_up) + color_z) / 3.0`. Assign res://assets/sprites/Rock022_2K-PNG_Color.png to shader parameter texture_x and texture_z, and res://assets/sprites/Grass002_2K-PNG_Color.png to shader parameter texture_y.

Add a TileMapLayer named Bench at position (160, 320), paint Bench with at least one tile from the TileSet, and add a child TileMapLayer named Highlight positioned at (160, 32) that remains empty.

tutorial_source: YouTube: GodotGameLab - Godot 4 Autobattler Tutorial: TileMapLayers & Particles (S1E1)
instruction: In scenes/main.tscn, add a GPUParticles2D node named DustParticles under a Node2D named Visuals. Set its position to (320, 180), z_index to 99, amount to 20, lifetime to 6, and assign assets/sprites/star_particle.png as the texture. Create a ParticleProcessMaterial with box emission (set emission shape to box and set the emission box extents X to 320), spread 180, initial velocity 20–30, angular velocity 20–40, set gravity Y to 0, scale min 0.1 max 0.2, and assign it to the particles. Add a CurveTexture as the scale_curve. Set the particle color alpha to a semi-transparent value between 0 and 1.

instruction: Add a Node2D named SpawningPoints under the Trap node. Inside SpawningPoints, create two Marker2D children named SpawnTop and SpawnBot. Place SpawnTop at the tip of the upper spike, and SpawnBot at the position of the tip of the lower spike; ensure each Marker2D's position is visually aligned with the sprite texture. Set SpawnBot's z_index to 1.

tutorial_source: YouTube: Godotneers - Particle Systems in Godot - Part 1: Getting started in 2D
instruction: Finish res://scenes/main.tscn so Rain's GPUParticles2D fills the 1800px-wide sky, emits ~800 drops for 5s with a 10s preprocess, 600-850 initial velocity along (0.1, 1, 0), scale 0.2-1.0, hide-on-contact collisions (base size ≈5), and a visibility rect that covers the whole screen (suppose the screen is 1800x900, starting at around (-900, -200)). Wire its sub_emitter to Splash and set the ParticleProcessMaterial to a box emission 900px wide with four Splash particles per collision. Configure Splash with its own ParticleProcessMaterial (align_y=true, 6400 amount, explosiveness 1, 50-60 velocity, gravity 98, scale 0.1-0.2) so Rain collisions burst extra droplets. Add assets/raindrop.png as texture to both Rain and Splash, while setting the modulate of both particles to a semi-transparent, unmistakably blue tint. Keep GroundOccluder and GroundCollider covering the floor so collisions work.

instruction: In the main scene, add a node named TrapTop by referencing the existing TrapBot's implementation. tutorial_source: YouTube: Nathan Hoad - Dialogue balloons with portraits in Godot 4
instruction: Build the portrait-ready dialogue balloon in `scenes/portrait_balloon.tscn`. Wrap the dialogue content in an `HBoxContainer` with a named TextureRect portrait slot (150×150 min size) alongside the VBox text column, set the separation to 30 px, and flag the portrait node as unique for scripts. Name the HBox node as `HBoxContainer`, and the portrait node `PortraitTexture`. Update the node order to ensure that the portrait appears to the right of the dialog text. Update the balloon theme so every MarginContainer side uses 30 px padding, the default font size is 26, the panel background switches to the "RPG blue" (#17438C) color, and the response buttons use matching blue normal/focus StyleBoxFlat resources (slightly darker blue for normal, and lighter blue for focus).

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Basic Inventory System [Part 1] - Godot 4.x
instruction: Author res://scripts/interactable_item.gd so it extends Node3D with class_name InteractableItem, exports a MeshInstance3D named item_highlight_mesh, hides that mesh in _ready(), and provides gain_focus() / lose_focus() methods that toggle its visibility. Attach the script to the RigidBody3D in res://scenes/item_pickup.tscn, set its collision_layer to 2, collision_mask to 3, and assign MeshInstance3D/Highlight to the export. Ensure the Highlight child stays hidden by default while using an emissive StandardMaterial3D for its outline; the highlight box mesh should have its normals inversed to appear as highlight, and the material must emit yellow color (#ffff00). Create res://scripts/item_data.gd as a Resource with exported item_name (String) and item_model_prefab (PackedScene), then add res://resources/items/test_cube.tres using that script so it stores the name "Test Cube" and points item_model_prefab to res://scenes/item_pickup.tscn. Leave the ItemPickup instance in res://scenes/main.tscn so the prefab is visible in the scene tree.

instruction: In Main.tscn, update the deprecated TileMap node under Main by replacing it with the newer TileMapLayer nodes: for each layer in TileMap, add a new TileMapLayer node as the child of TileMap while keeping its tilemap data and z-index. The child node's name should be the same as the original layer's name in TileMap. The order of child noes should be kept the same as the original order of the layers. Finally, change the node type of TileMap to Node2D while keeping its node name.

Solid tiles are defined as tiles in which at least 95% of the 18×18 pixels are opaque. This includes the dirt, grass, snow, mushroom platform, and box tiles in this tileset.

task_name: Build the gritty world environment skybox
tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Basic Post Processing in Godot 4
instruction: Under Main, configure the WorldEnvironment so its Environment keeps the procedural sky background (background_mode = Sky) with the ProceduralSkyMaterial's sky colors (both horizon and top) set to Color(0.0, 0.0, 0.0), set the Environment's sky cover to skybox2.png in assets/textures/, switches to ACES tone mapping, enables SSR with 128 max steps and 0.51 depth tolerance, enables SSAO at intensity 5.54, enables SDFGI with occlusion (bounce feedback 1.44, 6 cascades, 0.1 min cell size), and activates glow using LensDirtTexture.png with normalized screen blend (intensity 4.33, strength 0.88, bloom 0.05).

tutorial_source: YouTube: Bonkahe - Basic Post Processing in Godot 4
instruction: Enable linear fog in the shared WorldEnvironment, tint it to #848d9e with density 0.001 and sky affect 0.147, enable volumetric fog with albedo Color(0.8706, 0.7961, 0.7726), use FOG_MODE_DEPTH for fog_mode, and turn on Adjustments so the color correction slot uses the provided ExtremeLUT.png Texture3D as its lookup table.

tutorial_source: https://kidscancode.org/godot_recipes/4.x/ui/minimap/index.html
instruction: Implement the minimap UI frame and markers. Inside Main/CanvasLayer/Minimap, size the Minimap MarginContainer to 200x200 with 5px margins, add a NinePatchRect Frame using panel_woodDetail_blank.png with 64px patch margins, add a sibling MarginContainer named "Content" with 20px margins containing a TextureRect Grid set to Tile stretch with pattern_blueprintPaper.png, and under Grid create PlayerMarker/MobMarker/AlertMarker Sprite2D nodes using the arrow, red jewel, and yellow exclamation textures (PlayerMarker centered, Mob/Alert hidden). For all textures, use the provided .png files. Don't write any script or create new code file.

tutorial_source: https://kidscancode.org/godot_recipes/4.x/ui/minimap/index.html
instruction: Implement the minimap logic: export a Player reference and a zoom property with a clamped setter, cache the grid and marker prototypes, center the player marker after the first frame, compute grid_scale from the grid size and viewport, duplicate and show markers for every node in the minimap_objects group using their minimap_icon keys, store them in a 'markers' dictionary, rotate (player rotation + PI/2) and position markers each frame relative to the player (scaling to 0.75 and clamping when off the grid), implement _on_object_removed which removes and erases markers when called, and implement _on_gui_input which handles mouse wheel gui_input to adjust zoom. Ensure the world scene connects minimap_objects "removed" signals to the minimap while mobs/crates have the "removed" signals, expose each one's "minimap_icon", and ensure mobs/crates belong to the minimap_objects group.
